title: After a final decree has been issued in a chapter 11 case and plan payments are still being made can a creditor sue you?
question: Final decree was approved plan payments are still being made with no default. One of the creditors sent a demand and intent to sue me personally stating that they received plan payments they know we have been dismissed from the bankruptcy but the creditor does not feel they are getting paid enough.stating I should save myself the embarrassment of litigation. It’s been 2 weeks. Should I be expecting this from all my creditors that had personal guarantees. I’m failing to see the point of the last 5 years of this hell.
answers:
Based on the limited facts I know, this is likely a violation of the discharge order. Bankruptcy courts have the power of civil contempt under 11 U.S.C. § 105 and Federal Rule of Bankruptcy Procedure 9020. Pursuant to the Taggart case, a court may hold a creditor in civil contempt for violating a discharge order if there is no fair ground of doubt as to whether the order barred the creditor’s conduct.

Please contact me for a free consultation - I would love to assist you in this possible injunction violation. They are NOT allowed to contact you and attempt to collect more on a debt then what is provided for under the confirmed chapter 11 plan.

A confirmed plan in a chapter 11 which designates how creditors are to be paid, is a contract with those creditors. Was the chapter 11 filed by the business? The creditor had an opportunity to object to the proposed plan in terms of the payments and is bound by the plan. However, the business chapter 11 did not eliminate your personal guarantee. If the chapter 11 was filed by you personally, then it dealt with your personal liability and the creditor cannot pursue you otherwise. I recommend you talk with your bankruptcy attorney to get these issues clarified so you can determine how to proceed.

What does your lawyer say?

Generally the person that signed the guaranty is liable for the debt, absent an extensive release being part of the plan, which is unusual.

You should also discuss whether you should be defending, settling, or whether a bkcy filing a for you would be in your best interest,
